audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 22, Lesson 1. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Books for Unit 21 and Unit 22.
audio.notes: <visual:

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 9 in your Unit 21 Student Book. Whisper read the story “The History Lady.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.

Blend Words: Now that we’ve learned about irregular plural nouns, let’s blend some words that are singular nouns and irregular plural nouns to practice what we've learned. Listen as I sound out the first two words.

/mmmaaannn/, man. /mmmeeennn/, men. Now read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether’. Say the word nice and loud.

Multimodal mini-lesson. Irregular plural nouns. A plural noun stands for more than one of something. Many nouns add "s" or "e-s" to form the plural, as in "cats" and "boxes." However, some nouns do not. These nouns are known as irregular plural nouns.
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "cat" and "cats," then the words "box" and "boxes">

audio.transcription: Here are some examples of irregular plural nouns.
audio.notes: <visual: show two columns, the words "child," "mouse," and "man" in one column labeled "singular" and the words "children," "mice" and "men" in the second column labeled "plural">

audio.transcription: Practice saying a sentence for each of the following words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the words children, mice, men>

audio.transcription: Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about how the Earth is changing. First, look at the picture. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. sun <pause>, energy or sunlight <pause>, atmosphere <pause>, greenhouse gases <pause>, Earth. Look at the sun and the Earth in the picture. What does the Earth get from the sun?
Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about how the Earth is changing. The word is affects. Affects means “influences.”
Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
Now listen to “How Is Earth Changing?”
Do you have any wonderings or questions about how the Earth is changing? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 1 in your Unit 22 Student Book. The title of this story is "What’s Happening to Earth’s Climate?” Point to each word as you read the title with me: What’s Happening to Earth’s Climate? This story is about a girl who learns how the climate on Earth is changing. Climate is what the weather is like in a place, over a long period of time.

Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this story: shift. A shift is a change in something. I felt a shift in temperature because there was a cold breeze. What are some ways the temperature might shift throughout the year?
Read the story. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find the plurals of person and life on the first page of the story.
What climate shift did the girl learn about when she went to the rally? Find the sentences that answer the question.
How do you think the hurricane, thunderstorm, and tornado warning affected how the girl feels about climate change?
Why is it important to help with a cause you feel strongly about?
You can reread this story during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.
Write to Deepen Comprehension: Write one or two questions you have about climate. <pause> Share your ideas with a partner before you write. Look back at the story for ideas.

toc.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Substitute Initial and Final Sounds

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 22, Lesson 2. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 22.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 1 in your Unit 22 Student Book. Whisper read the story “What’s Happening to Earth’s Climate?” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 1 spread>

audio.transcription: Let's learn some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: against, certain, door, early, field>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word certain. Say the word with me. Certain. What syllables do you hear in certain? (cer-tain) There’s a lot to remember with this word. It begins with the soft c sound /s/ like circle. The last syllable t-a-i-n is pronounced and spelled just like the last syllable in mountain. That can help us remember it.
Spell the word with me: c-e-r-t-a-i-n. The word "certain" does not follow the rules. We have to pay extra attention to it to remember its spelling.
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: against, certain, door, early, field.

slides.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Substitute Initial and Final Sounds

audio.transcription: Listen as I say a word: train
audio.notes: <visual: show Phonemic Awareness image>

audio.transcription: Say the word train, but change the beginning sound. Change /t/, to /b/. What's the new word? <pause> brain
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.
Now let's change the ending sound of a word. Listen as I say a word: fork
Say the word fork, but change the ending sound. Change /k/, to /t/. What's the new word? <pause> fort
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.
Multimodal mini-lesson. Let's review irregular plural nouns. Irregular plural nouns do not form the plural by adding "s" or "e-s." Some irregular plural nouns have common spelling changes.
audio.notes: <visual: wife wife-fe+ves wives [show "ves" in red font]>

audio.transcription: Listen as I read the following word: "wife." To form the plural of "wife," first remove letters "f-e." <pause> Now replace them with letters "v-e-s." What is the new word?
wives.
Practice forming the plural for the following words with your teacher.
audio.notes: <visual: show the following words: wolf, life, leaf>

audio.transcription: Blend Words: Now that we’ve learned about irregular plural nouns, let’s blend some words that are singular nouns and irregular plural nouns to practice what we've learned. Listen as I sound out the first two words.
audio.notes: <visual: blend words table>

audio.transcription: /mmmaaannn/, man. /mmmeeennn/, men. Now read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether’. Say the word nice and loud.

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about how weather impacts bird migration. First, look at the picture. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. birds <pause>, trees <pause>, water. Look at the birds in the picture. Where do you think the birds are going?
audio.notes: <visual: show vocabulary card>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about how weather impacts bird migration. The word is challenges. Challenges are difficulties or problems.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, challenges>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words challenges and migrate>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “How Weather Impacts Bird Migration”
Do you have any wonderings or questions about how weather impacts bird migration? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 2 in your Unit 22 Student Book. The title of this text is "Moose on the Move.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: Moose on the Move. This text is a photo comic. It has panels and text boxes like a comic but uses photos and facts instead of illustrations and dialogue.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this text: suited. Suited means appropriate or matched. A polar bear’s fur is suited to its freezing home. What is an activity that is suited to you? Why?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, suited>

audio.transcription: Read the text. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find the plural of moose.
Where do moose migrate, or travel to? Find the sentences and text features that answer the question.
In what ways are moose suited for the environments where they live?
What else would you like to know about moose? How could you find more information about them?
You can reread this text during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.
Write to Deepen Comprehension: Write a list of three to five facts that you learned about moose. <pause> Draw a picture to accompany your list.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the writing journal>

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 22, Lesson 3. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 22.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 2 in your Unit 22 Student Book. Whisper read the story “Moose on the Move.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 2 spread>

audio.transcription: Review Phonics Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show phonics cards>

audio.transcription: Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show High-Frequency Word Cards>

audio.transcription: Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the pocket chart and word>

audio.transcription: Multimodal mini-lesson. Let's review irregular plural nouns. Irregular plural nouns do not form the plural by adding "s" or "e-s." Some irregular plural nouns have common spelling changes.
audio.notes: <visual: woman woman-an+en women [show "en" in red font]>

audio.transcription: Listen as I read the following word: "woman." To form the plural of "woman," change the letters "a-n" to "e-n." What is the new word?
women.
Practice forming the plural with vowel spelling changes for the following words with your teacher.
audio.notes: <visual: show the following words: man, tooth, foot>

audio.transcription: Blend Words: Now that we’ve learned about irregular plural nouns, let’s blend some words that are singular nouns and irregular plural nouns to practice what we've learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
audio.notes: <visual: show the blend words table>

audio.transcription: Let's find and underline each irregular plural in which the vowel or vowels changed.
Now, let's put a box around each irregular plural where the f was changed to a v.
Blending Focus: Use your letter cards to build each word I say. Let's start by doing one together. Make the word half. <pause> Change the f to make the plural of half. What word did you make? Halves
audio.notes: <visual: show Phonemic Awareness image>

audio.transcription: Listen carefully as your teacher tells you the letter or letters to change to make the next word with your letter cards.

Let's build this set of words again. This time your teacher will not tell you which letters to change. Let's try one together: Make the word half <pause>. Now change half to halves. Which sound is different? Which letter will be different?

Build Words Booster: Let's do some more word building. Listen carefully as your teacher tells you which word to make with your letter cards. Your teacher will check your work. Think about each sound in the word you are making. Use letter cards to spell the word.
audio.notes: <visual: show the letter cards to build the words>

audio.transcription: Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 3 in your Unit 22 Student Book. Today we are going to read some cumulative sentences. These sentences contain words with irregular plural nouns and other phonics skills we have learned. Let’s whisper read one sentence at a time. When you are done, we will chorally read them together.
audio.notes: <visual: Show Cumulative Sentences, pages 12-13>

audio.transcription: Circle all the words with irregular plural nouns. <pause> Turn to a partner and read the words. Your teacher will listen in.
Write a sentence using the word teeth. <pause> When you are finished, read your sentence to a partner.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence strips and word teeth>

audio.transcription: Write a sentence using each of these word pairs: people/children, sheep/deer.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence strips and word pairs people/children, sheep/deer>

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 22, Lesson 4. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 22.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 3 in your Unit 22 Student Book. Whisper read the cumulative sentences.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 3 spread>

audio.transcription: Introduce High-Frequency Words. Let's learn some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: heard, knew, listen, morning, several>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word listen. Say the word with me. Listen. The word "listen" does not follow the rules. We have to pay extra attention to it to remember its spelling.
Spell the word with me: l-i-s-t-e-n. The letter "t" is silent in the word "listen."
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: heard, knew, morning, several.

Listen to each word your teacher says. Write the word. If you need help, tap the sounds or use your sound boxes and counters to break up the word sound by sound. Then think about the letter that stands for each sound.
audio.notes: <visual: show Phonemic Awareness image>

audio.transcription: Let's start with these two words. Write the word feet.
Now write the word people.
Spelling Booster: Let's write some more words. Listen to each word I say. Break apart the word sound by sound, then write the letter or spelling for each sound.
audio.notes: <visual: show Spelling Booster image>

audio.transcription: tooth
teeth
man
men
shelf
selves
fish
Multimodal mini-lesson. Let's review irregular plural nouns. Irregular plural nouns do not form the plural by adding "s" or "e-s." Some irregular plural nouns have common spelling changes.
audio.notes: <visual: show two columns, the words "child" and "person" in one column labeled "singular" and the words "children" and "people" in the second column labeled "plural">

audio.transcription: Here are some examples of irregular plural nouns.
Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Then, read each word as your teacher taps on it.
audio.notes: <visual: show the blend words table>

audio.transcription: Select two words from the list. Write a sentence using both words.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 4 in your Unit 22 Student Book. The title of this text is "Listen to This!" Point to each word as you read the title with me: Listen to This! This text is a photo comic. It has panels, speech bubbles, and text boxes like a comic but uses photos together with illustrations. Read the photo comic. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Find the word in the photo comic with the irregular plural and circle them. <pause> Chorally read the circled word.
Write the sentence I say. Listen carefully and focus on one word at a time.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the writing journal>

audio.transcription: The first sentence is: Several children can hop on one foot. Say the sentence with me: Several children can hop on one foot. Now write the sentence. Your teacher will help you segment, or break apart, each word and write a letter for each sound.

The second sentence is: This morning I saw sheep and geese in the field. Say the sentence with me: This morning I saw sheep and geese in the field. Now write the sentence. Your teacher will help you if you need it.
Let's read each sentence out loud. Check your work. Your teacher will write each sentence. Correct your spellings if necessary.

Let's review irregular plural nouns. Remember that a plural noun stands for "more than one of something." Many nouns add "s" or "es" to form the plural. However, some nouns do not. These nouns are irregular.
Some irregular plural nouns can be formed by changing the vowel or vowels in the word. For example, the singular noun "man" is made plural by changing the "a" to an "e."
audio.notes: <visual: show word card "man" with a label above it that says "singular" and the word card "men" with a label above it that says "plural">

audio.transcription: Some irregular plural nouns can be formed by changing the "f" or "f-e" in the words to "v-e-s." For example, the plural form of the noun "leaf" is "leaves."
audio.notes: <visual: show word card "leaf" with a label above it that says "singular" and the word card "leaves" with a label above it that says "plural">

audio.transcription: Some irregular plural nouns do not follow any rules. For example, the plural form of the noun "person" is "people."
audio.notes: <visual: show word card "person" with a label above it that says "singular" and the word card "people" with a label above it that says "plural">

audio.transcription: Some words, such as "sheep" and "fish," do not change when they are plural.
audio.notes: <visual: show word card "sheep" with a label above it that says "singular" and the word card "sheep" with a label above it that says "plural">

audio.transcription: Do you know the plural form of these nouns?
audio.notes: <visual: show the word cards "tooth" "loaf" "mouse" "deer">

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 22, Lesson 5. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 22.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 4 in your Unit 22 Student Book. Whisper read the story “Listen to This!” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 4 spread>

audio.transcription: Review Phonics Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show phonics cards>

audio.transcription: Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show High-Frequency Word Cards>

audio.transcription: Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the pocket chart and word>

audio.transcription: Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about heat waves, drought, and wildfires. First, look at these five pictures. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. hot summer day <pause>, drought <pause>, sun <pause>, water <pause>, wildfire <pause>, trees. Look at the picture of a hot summer day. How do people cool off during hot weather?
audio.notes: <visual: show vocabulary card>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about heat waves, drought, and wildfires. The word is shortage. Shortage means “a lack of something that is needed.”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, shortage>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words shortage and persist>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “The Heat Is On!”
Do you have any wonderings or questions about heat waves, drought, and wildfires? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 5 in your Unit 22 Student Book. The title of this text is "It’s Too Hot!” Point to each word as you read the title with me: It’s Too Hot! You will read about more effects of climate change.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this text: consequence. A consequence is the result or effect of something. A consequence of eating too many sweets can be a stomachache. What might be the consequence of going outside in the rain without an umbrella?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, consequence>

audio.transcription: Read the text. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find two irregular plural nouns on the second page of the text.
What is one example of a consequence, or effect, of a heat wave? Find sentences that answer this question.
Why does the author say that extreme weather is dangerous?
How would you describe the weather today where you live? How would you describe the climate where you live?
You can reread this text during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.

Write to Deepen Comprehension: Draw pictures to create a cause-effect chart to show some of the effects of a heat wave. <pause> Write a sentence to explain what is happening in each picture. <pause> You will use this information to write a short summary of the effects of a heat wave. Share your summary with a partner before writing.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the writing journal>

audio.transcription: Let's review irregular plural nouns. Remember that a plural noun stands for "more than one of something." Many nouns add "s" or "es" to form the plural. However, some nouns do not. These nouns are irregular.
audio.notes: <visual: show word card "man" with a label above it that says "singular" and the word card "men" with a label above it that says "plural">

audio.transcription: To form the plural of the noun "woman" the letter "a" must change to an "e."
audio.notes: <visual: show word card "woman" with a label above it that says "singular" and the word card "women" with a label above it that says "plural">

audio.transcription: Some irregular plural nouns can be formed by changing the "f" or "f-e" in the words to "v-e-s." For example, the plural form of the noun "scarf" is "scarves."
audio.notes: <visual: show word card "scarf" with a label above it that says "singular" and the word card "scarves" with a label above it that says "plural">

audio.transcription: Some irregular plural nouns do not follow any rules. For example, the plural form of the noun "person" is "people."
audio.notes: <visual: show word card "person" with a label above it that says "singular" and the word card "people" with a label above it that says "plural">

audio.transcription: Some words, such as "moose" do not change when they are plural.
audio.notes: <visual: show word card "moose" with a label above it that says "singular" and the word card "moose" with a label above it that says "plural">

audio.transcription: Do you know the plural form of these nouns?
audio.notes: <visual: show the word cards "foot" "loaf" "child" "shrimp">

audio.transcription: Look at these words. Let's read the words together: wife, wives, leaf, leaves, foot, feet, teeth, mice, person, people, shrimp, moose, fish. Now look at these two categories. This is the word wife. Read the word with me. <pause> Which category should I put wife under? <pause> Yes, wife goes in the singular category because the word wife is only one wife, not more than one. With your partner, continue to sort the rest of the words.
audio.notes: <visual: show wordswife, wives, leaf, leaves, foot, feet, teeth, mice, person, people, shrimp, moose, fish> <visual: show word wife> <visual: show the sorting cards plural, singular, and both in a pocket chart>

audio.transcription: What did you notice about the words in each group?
You will notice singular and pluran nouns in your reading. As we read, let's look for words that are singular, plural, or both.
Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 22, Lesson 6. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 22.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 5 in your Unit 22 Student Book. Whisper read the text “It’s Too Hot!” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 5 spread>

audio.transcription: Listen as I say a word: mean
audio.notes: <visual: show Phonemic Awareness image>

audio.transcription: Say the word mean, but change the middle sound. Change /ē/, to /ō/. What's the new word? <pause> moan
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.
Multimodal mini-lesson. Let's review irregular plural nouns. Irregular plural nouns do not form the plural by adding "s" or "e-s." Some irregular plural nouns have common spelling changes.
audio.notes: <visual: foot foot-oot+eet feet [show "eet" in red font]>

audio.transcription: Listen as I read the following word: "foot." To form the plural of "foot," change the letters "o-o-t" to "e-e-t." What is the new word?
feet.
Practice forming the plural with vowel spelling changes for the following words with your teacher.
audio.notes: <visual: show the following words: tooth, goose>

audio.transcription: Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Say the sound for each letter or spelling as your teacher points to it. Blend the sounds to read the word. Now read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
audio.notes: <visual: show the blend words table>

audio.transcription: Let's review some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: against, certain, door, early, field, heard, knew, listen, morning, several>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word against. Say the word with me: "against"
Spell the word with me: a-g-a-i-n-s-t. The word "against" does not follow the rules. We have to pay extra attention to it to remember its spelling.
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it. Then, use the word in a sentence.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: against, certain, door, early, field, heard, knew, listen, morning, several.

Build Words Booster: Let's do some more word building. Listen carefully as your teacher tells you which word to make with your letter cards. Your teacher will check your work. Think about each sound in the word you are making. Use letter cards to spell the word.
audio.notes: <visual: show the letter cards to build the words>

audio.transcription: Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 6 in your Unit 22 Student Book. Today we are going to read some cumulative sentences. These sentences contain words with irregular plural nouns and other phonics skills we have learned. Let’s whisper read one sentence at a time. When you are done, we will chorally read them together.
audio.notes: <visual: Show Cumulative Sentences, pages 18-19>

audio.transcription: Circle all the irregular plural nouns. <pause> Turn to a partner and read the words. Your teacher will listen in.
Write a sentence using the word feet. <pause> When you are finished, read your sentence to a partner.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence strips and word feet>

audio.transcription: Write a sentence using each of these word pairs: feet/teeth, knives/loaves.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence strips and word pairs feet/teeth, knives/loaves>

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 22, Lesson 7. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 22.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 6 in your Unit 22 Student Book. Whisper read the cumulative sentences. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 6 spread>

audio.transcription: Review Phonics Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show phonics cards>

audio.transcription: Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show High-Frequency Word Cards>

audio.transcription: Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the pocket chart and word>

audio.transcription: Multimodal mini-lesson. Let's review irregular plural nouns. Irregular plural nouns do not form the plural by adding "s" or "e-s." Some irregular plural nouns have common spelling changes.
audio.notes: <visual: show two columns, the words "man" and "woman" in one column labeled "singular" and the words "men" and "women" in the second column labeled "plural">

audio.transcription: Here are some examples of irregular plural nouns. These plural nouns are formed by changing a vowel spelling.

Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
audio.notes: <visual: show the blend words table>

audio.transcription: Let's review some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: against, certain, door, early, field, heard, knew, listen, morning, several.>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word certain. Say the word with me: "certain"
Spell the word with me: c-e-r-t-a-i-n. The word "certain" does not follow the rules. We have to pay extra attention to it to remember its spelling.
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it. Then, use the word in a sentence.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: against, door, early, field, heard, knew, listen, morning, several.

Let's do some more work with this unit's high-frequency words. Read: Look at the high-frequency words. Read each word along with me. against, <pause> certain, <pause> door, <pause> early, <pause> field, <pause> heard, <pause> knew, <pause> listen, <pause> morning, <pause> several.
audio.notes: <visual: show "against, certain, door, early, field, heard, knew, listen, morning, several" as cards in pocket-chart pockets, add one blank pocket-row, show tray with only letters for the first word.> [intended for teacher to model the first word]

audio.transcription: Build: Now let's build a word together. Watch as your teacher spells the word.
Now use your letter cards to build all the words.
Write: Write each word. Then write a sentence using each word. For example, you can start a sentence with "I am certain that ______ ." Read your sentences to a partner when you are done.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence frame "I am certain that [blank]." Then show "against, certain, door, early, field, heard, knew, listen, morning, several" as cards in pocket-chart pockets underneath sentence frame>

audio.transcription: Now your teacher is going to make a word with letter cards. <pause> What is the word? <pause> Spell it together. <pause> Watch as your teacher scrambles the letters. Fix the spelling.
audio.notes: <visual: empty pocket rows with tray with letter cards for 2nd word>

audio.transcription: Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 7 in your Unit 22 Student Book. The title of this text is "Weather and Climate." Point to the word as you read the title with me: Weather and Climate. This is a chart that compares and contrasts weather and climate. It tells how weather and climate are alike and different.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: What do you notice or wonder about when viewing the chart?
Create a chart that compares and contrasts two weather events, such as a thunderstorm and a blizzard.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the writing journal>

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 22, Lesson 8. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 22.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 7 in your Unit 22 Student Book. Whisper read the text “Weather and Climate.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 7 spread>

audio.transcription: Multimodal mini-lesson. Let's review irregular plural nouns. Irregular plural nouns do not form the plural by adding "s" or "e-s." Some irregular plural nouns have common spelling changes.
audio.notes: <visual: show two columns, the words "child" and "person" in one column labeled "singular" and the words "children" and "people" in the second column labeled "plural">

audio.transcription: Here are some examples of irregular plural nouns. These plural nouns don't follow any rules and will have to be memorized.
Listen as I read the following word: "mouse." To form the plural of "mouse," change the letters "o-u-s-e" to "i-c-e." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: mouse mouse-ouse+ice mice [show "ice" in red font]>

audio.transcription: mice.
Practice forming the plural of the following word with your teacher.
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "ox">

audio.transcription: Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
audio.notes: <visual: show the blend words table>

audio.transcription: Let's find and underline all the irregular plural nouns that have to be memorized.
Now, let's put a box around each plural in which the vowel or vowels changed.

Blending Focus: Use your letter cards to build each word I say. Let's start by doing one together. Make the word trap. <pause> Make man. Change the vowel in man to make it plural. What word did you make? Men
audio.notes: <visual: show the letter cards to build the words>

audio.transcription: Listen carefully as your teacher tells you the letter or letters to change to make the next word with your letter cards.

Let's build this set of words again. This time your teacher will not tell you which letters to change. Let's try one together: Make the word man <pause>. Now change man to men. Which sound is different? Which letter will be different?

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about dust storms and sandstorms. First, look at the picture. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. sky <pause>, dust storm <pause>, street <pause>, city. Look at the dust storm in the picture. What is the dust storm covering?
audio.notes: <visual: show vocabulary card>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about dust storms and sandstorms. The word is lack. If there is a lack of something, there is not enough of it.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, lack>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words lack and launch>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “Storms Made of Sand and Dust”
Do you have any wonderings or questions about dust storms and sandstorms? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 8 in your Unit 22 Student Book. The title of this text is "Dust Storm!” Point to each word as you read the title with me: Dust Storm! You will read a text about the dust storms that took place in the Midwest nearly one hundred years ago.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this text: erosion. Erosion is the breaking away of soil and rocks caused by wind, water, and other forces. Waves can cause sand erosion at the beach. How do you think wind and water cause erosion? Tell about your ideas.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, erosion>

audio.transcription: Read the text. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find three irregular plural nouns on the first page.
How did erosion play a part in the dust storms of the 1930s? Find the sentences that answer this question.
Why did many people leave their homes during the dust storms? Why do you think other people stayed?
Imagine that your family lived through the dust storms. What do you think it was like?
You can reread this text during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.
Write to Deepen Comprehension: Work with a partner to research how farmers changed their methods so dust storms would be less likely to happen again.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the writing journal>

audio.transcription: Let's review syllable types. Words are made up of syllables. For example, the words "public," "basic," "reason," and "margin" each have two syllables. Each syllable has one vowel sound. We can use what we know about syllables and spelling patters to read longer words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the words "public" "basic" "reason" and "margin">

audio.transcription: Closed syllables are syllables that have a short vowel sound. When two or more consonants appear in the middle of a word, divide the word between the consonants.
audio.notes: <visual: show the word public>

audio.transcription: The word "public" has two closed syllalbles: "pub" <pause> "lic".
audio.notes: <visual: show the word public broken up into two cards: pub lic>

audio.transcription: Open syllables are syllables that end in a vowel and have a long vowel sound. When one consonant appears between two vowels, divide the word before and after the consonant.
audio.notes: <visual: show the word basic>

audio.transcription: The word "basic" has one open syllable: "ba" and one closed syllable: "sic."
audio.notes: <visual: show the word basic broken up into two cards: ba sic>

audio.transcription: Vowel team syllables are syllables that contain a vowel team. The vowel team always stays together in the same syllable.
audio.notes: <visual: show the word reason>

audio.transcription: The word reason has one vowel team syllable: "rea" <pause> "son."
audio.notes: <visual: show the word reason broken up into two cards: rea son>

audio.transcription: R-controlled vowel syllables have an r-controlled vowel. The letters that make up the r-controlled vowel spelling stay together in the same syllable.
audio.notes: <visual: show the word margin>

audio.transcription: The word margin has two syllables: "mar" <pause> "gin." The first syllable is an r-controlled vowel syllable.
audio.notes: <visual: show the word margin broken up into two cards: mar gin>

audio.transcription: Practice identifying the different syllable types in the following words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the following words: subject, vacant, contain, turkey>

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 22, Lesson 9. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 22.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 8 in your Unit 22 Student Book. Whisper read the story “Dust Storm!” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 8 spread>

audio.transcription: Review Phonics Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show phonics cards>

audio.transcription: Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show High-Frequency Word Cards>

audio.transcription: Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the pocket chart and word>

audio.transcription: Multimodal mini-lesson. Let's review irregular plural nouns. Some words, such as "deer," stay the same whether they are singular or plural.
audio.notes: <visual: show the word deer in two columns, one labeled singular and one labeled plural>

audio.transcription: What do you notice about the following words?
audio.notes: <visual: show each of the following words twice next to each other, once in black font, once in red font: sheep, fish, moose>

audio.transcription: They're the same. These are examples of more words that stay the same whether they are singular or plural.
Blend Words: Let's blend some words to practice what we've learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Say the word nice and loud.
audio.notes: <visual: show the blend words table>

audio.transcription: Select two words from the list. Write a sentence for each word.

Listen to each word your teacher says. Write the word. If you need help, tap the sounds or use your sound boxes and counters to break up the word sound by sound. Then think about the letter that stands for each sound.
audio.notes: <visual: show Phonemic Awareness image>

audio.transcription: Let's start with these two words. Write the word wolf.
Now write the word wolves.
Finally, write this sentence: The women saw some mice in the leaves.

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about blizzards. First, look at the picture. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. blizzard <pause>, tree <pause>, ice <pause>, car <pause>, snow <pause>, road. Look at the picture of the blizzard. What do you notice about the road?
audio.notes: <visual: show vocabulary card>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about blizzards. The word is average. Average means “common or usual.”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, average>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words average and present>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “Blizzards Bring Snow—and Danger”
Do you have any wonderings or questions about blizzards? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 9 in your Unit 22 Student Book. The title of this story is "Sam Kent's Journal.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: Sam Kent's Journal. This passage is a journal entry written by a man visiting the Grand Canyon.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this story: account. An account is a telling of events or a report. Dad gave an account of what happened on his way home. When have you given an account of something that happened?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, account>

audio.transcription: Read the story. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find an irregular plural noun in the second paragraph.
What does Sam Kent see as he looks down into the canyon? Find the sentences that answer the question.
Why do you think Sam Kent wrote this account in his journal?
Would you like to visit the Grand Canyon? Why or why not? Use details from Sam Kent’s journal to support your answer.
You can reread this story during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.
Write to Deepen Comprehension: Write a journal entry for Sam Kent’s day rafting with his family. <pause> Share your ideas with a partner before writing.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the writing journal>

toc.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Blend and Segment Multisyllabic Words by Syllable

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 22, Lesson 10. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 22.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 9 in your Unit 22 Student Book. Whisper read the story “Sam Kent’s Journal.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 1 spread>

audio.transcription: Let's make a word ladder. I will give you a clue for each word to write on the word ladder.
audio.notes: <visual: empty word ladder with 6 rungs>

audio.transcription: Write the word fishing.
Replace the ending in fishing to make a word that means “like a fish.”
Delete the suffix in fishy to name a water animal that has gills.
Add three letters to the beginning of fish to make a word that means “concerned only with yourself, not others.”
Take away the suffix in selfish to make a word that means “one’s own being.”
Change the ending of self to make the word plural.
Now your teacher will ask you to read and write some words to check on your progress. Congratulations on all your hard work in Unit 22!
audio.notes: <visual: show Cumulative Assessment page 30>

slides.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Blend and Segment Multisyllabic Words by Syllable

audio.transcription: Listen as I say the following syllables: hill-top
audio.notes: <visual: show Phonemic Awareness image>

audio.transcription: Repeat the syllables and blend them to make a word. Hill-top, hilltop.
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following syllables. Blend the syllables to make a word.
Now we will segment words into syllables. Listen as I say the following word: reuse
Repeat the word and segment it into the syllables you hear. Reuse, re-use.
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words. Segment each word into the syllables you hear.
Let's do some more work with this unit's high-frequency words. Look at the high-frequency words.
audio.notes: <visual: against, certain, door, early, field, heard, knew, listen, morning, several>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher reads a high-frequency word from the list. Point to the word. Read the word. Spell the the word aloud.

Now build each high-frequency word using letter cards. Then work with a partner. Take turns scrambling the letters in the words. Rebuild each word. Watch as your teacher models scrambling and rebuilding the word "door."
audio.notes: <visual: pocket chart with 3rd word spelled out with letter cards: door>

audio.transcription: Let's review syllables. Each syllable has one vowel sound. We can use what we know about syllables and spelling patters to read longer words. The words "helmet," "bacon," "reveal," and "ever" each have two syllables.
audio.notes: <visual: show the words "helmet" "bacon" and "reveal" "ever">

audio.transcription: When two or more consonants appear in the middle of a word, divide the word between the consonants. The word "helmet" has two closed syllables: "hel" <pause> "met" <pause> "helmet."
audio.notes: <visual: show the word helmet broken up into two cards: hel-met>

audio.transcription: When one consonant appears between two vowels, divide the word before and after the consonant. The word "bacon" has one open syllable "ba" and one closed syllable "con." "ba" <pause> "con" <pause> "bacon."
audio.notes: <visual: show the word bacon broken up into two cards: ba-con>

audio.transcription: The word "reveal" has one open syllable "re" and one closed syllable "veal." "re" <pause> "veal" <pause> "reveal."
audio.notes: <visual: show the word reveal broken up into two cards: re-veal>

audio.transcription: The word "ever" has two closed syllables, "ev" <pause> "ver" <pause> "ever."
audio.notes: <visual: show the word ever broken up into two cards: ev-ver>

audio.transcription: Practice dividing the following words into syllables.
audio.notes: <visual: show the words: "magnet," "lady," "window," "discard">
